question: [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: handle_dump_consensus_db_request()] [Missing Authentication] Does this endpoint implement ANY authentication or authorization checks before allowing consensus database dumps, or can any attacker with network access to the admin service extract complete consensus state including last_vote, highest_tc, all blocks, and QCs, enabling them to analyze consensus patterns for strategic Byzantine attacks? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: handle_dump_quorum_store_db_request()] [Missing Authentication] Is there authentication protecting the quorum store dump endpoint at line 40-72, or can unauthenticated attackers retrieve all batch digests and transaction batches from the quorum store, allowing them to front-run transactions or analyze transaction ordering for MEV attacks? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: handle_dump_block_request()] [Missing Authentication] Does handle_dump_block_request() verify caller identity before exposing block contents and extracted transactions, or can external attackers dump complete transaction history including user transaction data, signatures, and payload information without authorization? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: handle_dump_consensus_db_request()] [Privilege Escalation] Can a compromised non-validator node call this admin endpoint to gain access to validator-only consensus data like voting records and timeout certificates, allowing them to impersonate validator behavior or predict future consensus decisions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: handle_dump_block_request()] [Authorization Bypass] Does the 'bcs' parameter parsing at lines 92-98 introduce an authorization bypass where attackers can craft requests with specific boolean values to extract BCS-encoded transaction data that bypasses normal API access controls? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: dump_consensus_db()] [Consensus State Leakage] Does dumping last_vote at line 136 expose the validator's most recent voting decision, allowing malicious validators to correlate this information across multiple nodes to identify voting patterns and predict future votes for targeted censorship attacks? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: dump_consensus_db()] [Safety Data Exposure] Can exposing highest_tc (timeout certificate) at line 137 leak critical safety rule state that reveals which rounds have timed out, enabling attackers to craft malicious proposals that exploit known timeout patterns to violate AptosBFT safety guarantees? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: dump_consensus_db()] [Block Metadata Leakage] Do the block details dumped at lines 140-149 (including author, epoch, round, parent_id, timestamp, payload) provide sufficient information for attackers to reverse-engineer the consensus state machine and identify vulnerable round transitions for double-spending attacks? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: dump_consensus_db()] [QC Exposure] Does exposing all quorum certificates at lines 151-154 reveal validator signatures and voting patterns that could be used to forge QCs, manipulate vote aggregation, or identify Byzantine validators for coordination attacks? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: dump_blocks()] [Transaction Privacy Violation] Can extract_txns_from_block() at line 194 expose private transaction details including sender addresses, recipient addresses, amounts, and signatures before they are publicly committed, enabling front-running or censorship attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: dump_quorum_store_db()] [Batch Content Exposure] Does get_batch() at line 168 expose transaction batch contents that should be encrypted or kept private until commit time, allowing attackers to analyze pending transactions for arbitrage or MEV opportunities? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: dump_blocks_bcs()] [User Data Leakage] Can the BCS-encoded transaction dump at lines 232-233 expose sensitive user data including Move function arguments, resource contents, or private transaction metadata that violates user privacy expectations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: dump_consensus_db()] [Validator Identity Exposure] Does including block.author() at line 143 create a mapping between validator identities and their proposal patterns, enabling targeted DoS attacks or social engineering against specific high-value validators? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: handle_dump_consensus_db_request()] [Memory Exhaustion] Can an attacker repeatedly call this endpoint to force the validator to load the entire consensus database into memory via spawn_blocking at line 23, causing OOM crashes and loss of liveness if the database contains millions of blocks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: handle_dump_quorum_store_db_request()] [Unbounded Iteration] Does get_all_batches() at line 171 iterate over the entire quorum store without pagination limits, allowing attackers to trigger memory exhaustion by forcing enumeration of millions of batches accumulated over time? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: dump_blocks()] [O(n²) Complexity Attack] Can the nested iteration at lines 190-204 (iterating all blocks and all batches for each block) create O(n²) complexity that allows attackers to cause validator slowdown by requesting block dumps when both databases are large? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: handle_dump_block_request()] [Concurrent Dump DoS] Can multiple concurrent requests to dump blocks with bcs=true at lines 107-113 spawn multiple blocking tasks that exhaust the async runtime's blocking thread pool, preventing legitimate consensus operations from executing? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: dump_blocks_bcs()] [Memory Allocation Attack] Does all_txns.extend() at line 232 allocate unbounded memory when dumping all blocks without size limits, allowing attackers to trigger OOM by requesting dumps during periods of high transaction volume? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: dump_consensus_db()] [String Concatenation DoS] Can the repeated body.push_str() operations at lines 136-154 with large consensus databases cause quadratic string reallocation behavior, creating CPU exhaustion attacks that slow down validator consensus participation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: handle_dump_block_request()] [Database Lock Contention] Does accessing consensus_db.consensus_db().get_data() at line 188 acquire read locks that block consensus write operations, allowing attackers to cause consensus delays by repeatedly dumping blocks during critical voting periods? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: handle_dump_quorum_store_db_request()] [Hash Collision Attack] Can an attacker provide a crafted 'digest' parameter at line 47-53 that parses to a HashValue but collides with existing batch digests, causing get_batch() to return incorrect batch data or trigger database corruption? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: handle_dump_block_request()] [Hash Collision Attack] Does the block_id HashValue parsing at lines 82-88 validate that the hash is a valid block ID format, or can attackers provide hash collisions that match unrelated data structures causing type confusion in the consensus database? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: handle_dump_block_request()] [Boolean Parsing Injection] Can the bcs parameter parsing at lines 92-98 be exploited with non-boolean string values that cause unexpected parse() behavior, potentially triggering panic or bypassing intended serialization logic? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: handle_dump_quorum_store_db_request()] [Query Parameter Injection] Does the form_urlencoded::parse() at line 45 properly sanitize query parameters, or can attackers inject special characters or encoding tricks that bypass digest validation and access unauthorized batch data? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-admin-service/src/server/consensus/mod.rs] [Function: handle_dump_block_request()] [Missing Input Bounds] Is there validation that block_id exists in the database before calling dump_blocks() at line 111, or can attackers provide arbitrary hash values that cause expensive database scans searching for non-existent blocks? (Medium)
